note.p: John B. Deason was an attorney, politician, and Confederate officer during the Civil War.

Born on July 21, 1824, in Trigg County, Kentucky, Deason moved to Mississippi as a young man. He served as an officer during the Mexican American War, and returned to Mississippi where he practiced law and became an emerging public figure in Copiah County. Deason was a delegate to Mississippi’s secession convention in January 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency. Like nearly all attendees, he voted in support of the state separating from the Union. He volunteered for military service, helped raise volunteers for the Mississippi state troops, and was eventually commissioned as a colonel in command of the Third Mississippi Infantry Regiment, a unit comprised of volunteers from Mississippi’s gulf coast area. He led the regiment in a coastal defense assignment, and engaged Union troops at Biloxi in April 1862. The Third Mississippi’s enlistments ended in May 1862, at which point it was reorganized and most of the soldiers reenlisted. However, Deason departed the regiment at that time.

After the Civil War, Deason served as a chancellor and district attorney during most of the Reconstruction period. Around 1875, he moved to Brookhaven, where he held a variety of public positions, including mayor, postmaster, and represented Lincoln County in the Mississippi legislature. He died on March 29, 1900. Deason was married to Mary Ann Keller and had at least five children that lived to adulthood. He is buried in Rose Hill Cemetery in Brookhaven, Mississippi.

(The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, April 4, 1900; The Democratic-Herald, Charleston, MS, April 12, 1900; FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 536)

Albert G. Packer was a Union soldier during the Civil War and later served as a Mississippi state senator and adjutant general in Mississippi during Reconstruction. Born in 1843 in Massachusetts, Packer served in the Union army, eventually rising to the rank of captain. During the Reconstruction era, he settled in Mississippi and was elected senator representing the state’s Fifteenth District. By 1875, he served as the adjutant general, with the rank of brigadier general, in Mississippi, overseeing the state’s militia forces, under Republican governor Adelbert Ames. After Reconstruction, Packer moved to Virginia. He died there on April 26, 1921 and is buried in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, December 25, 1869, and June 26, 1875)

Joseph Ferdinand Sessions was a lawyer, Mississippi state senator, and Confederate Major of the Seventh Mississippi Infantry.

Born on November 13, 1838 in Franklin, Mississippi, Sessions was a farmer prior to the outbreak of the Civil War. During the war, he enlisted into the Confederate Army, ending the conflict with a rank of Major of the Seventh Mississippi Infantry. After the war, he moved to Brookhaven, Mississippi, where he became a lawyer, and from 1874 to 1875, he served as a Senator in the Mississippi legislature. In 1880, he was appointed as a U.S. Postmaster in Franklin, Mississippi.
Sessions was married to Susan Eliza (Dunckley) Sessions, and he had one son and one daughter. Sessions died on November 26, 1896 and was bured in Rose Hill Cemetery in Brookhaven, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Census Record for Franklin, Mississippi, 1860; Census Record for Brookhaven, Mississippi, 1880; H. Cassedy Jr. to A. K. Davis, September 25, 1874, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_803-992-12-010; Lincoln County, MS, MSGenWeb Project; Appointments of U.S. Postmasters, 1832-1971)

note.p: Alexander K. Davis was a representative in the Mississippi legislature and served as the state’s lieutenant governor from 1874 to 1876, during Reconstruction. He was the first African American lieutenant governor of Mississippi.

Little was recorded of Davis’ past. His date and place of birth are not known. During testimony before Congress in 1871 he explained that he moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, from Tennessee in 1869, and said he had been admitted to the bar (a reference that he had been accepted as a practicing attorney in a city or county), but did not specify in which state. He won a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives shortly after coming to Mississippi and became a leading figure in the state’s Republican Party circles. In 1873, Radical Republicans backed by a majority of African American voters in Mississippi, won a series of state elections. Davis was one of three African Americans elected to statewide office that year, winning the lieutenant governor seat. (The other Black figures to win statewide election were James Hill as secretary of state and T. W. Cardozo as state superintendent of education.) The following year, white conservatives carried out a campaign of intimidation and violence to suppress Republican and African American voting and put Democrats into political power. The effort worked and by 1875, Democrats held a majority of state legislative seats. Emboldened by their political power, Democrats tried to rid Republicans from many state positions. They specifically targeted Davis and northern-born and Radical Republican Governor Adelbert Ames, accusing both men of improprieties in office. Davis was charged with illegal granting of pardons. Despite his effort to fight the trumped-up charges, Mississippi Democrats impeached Davis in March 1876. Knowing that the conviction would result in him being removed from office, Davis resigned. Governor Ames, also facing politically-driven impeachment proceedings that would require extensive time and financial resources to fight, resigned as well. Following his resignation, Davis abandoned politics. He moved to Canton, Mississippi and worked as a pastor. He died on November 21, 1884.
(Wikipedia; Dernoral Davis, "Alexander K. Davis," Mississippi Encyclopedia; Clyde Tucker, “Alexander K. Davis (?-1884),” Black Past)

"Criminaliz[ing] the act of selling or supplying alcohol to a minor" or an underage person. During the nineteenth century, most states did not define a legal drinking age and of those that did during Reconstruction, the age was typically eighteen or twenty-one, and other states only required parental consent. (Justia; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi High Court of Errors and Appeals was created by the 1832 state constitution and was comprised of three popularly-elected justices. It remained the highest appellate court in the state until 1869, when it was replaced by the state Supreme Court. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p:
Brookhaven Miss.
July. 10th 1875.
Govr. A. K. Davis
Drsr.

Mr F Hartman makes application, to have imprisonment remitted in a case, in which he was some time since convicted for Selling liquors to a minor. As the Grand Father, of the minor to whom the liquors, are alleged to have been sold I would Say, that the remission of the imprisonment of Mr Hartman, would be agreeable to all concerned. Therefore I would respectfully ask that, Said imprisonment be remitted

I have the honor
to be respectfully
your obt Svt
Mayors Office Brookhaven July 10/75
To His Excellency A. K. Davis, Govorner of Miss.

On the 6th day of February A D 1874 Mr Frank Hartman a citizen of our city was tried before the Mayor on a charge of selling Whiskey to a minor. The judgment of the court was that the defendant Hartman be confined in the county Jail Ten days and pay a fine of $2000. The defendant appealed to the circuit court. the cause coming up in that court it was dismissed on the ground of informality of appeal Bond. the defendant then carried the case to high court. in that court the Judgment of the circuit court was affirmed & Mandate returned, which has just been received by me. Mr Hartman is petitioning your Excellency for clemency so far as the Imprisonment is concerned.

I do not see that enforcing the judgment so far as the imprisonment goes would enhance the cause of morality and good order as he (the defendant) has abandoned the ^Whiskey^ business and is engaged in other business. There are other circumstances connected with the prosecution which are mitigating. the whiskey was sold by a clerk & not by Hartman himself. I hope your Excellency may deem it consistent with your duty to remit the Imprisonment which ^is^ all that Mr H—desires
Verry Respectfully yours &c
W P Baggett Mayor of Brookhaven

[fold]
OFFICE OF
SECRETARY OF STATE
Jackson, July 13 1875

To his Excellency,
Govr. A K. Davis
Drsr

I have the honor to make the following Statement. That in the year 1874 Mr Frank Hartman of Lincoln county was sentenced by G W Haskins esqr. to pay a fine & be imprisoned in the County Jail, for a period of ten days for selling liquors to a minor, from which decision Mr Hartman appealed to the circuit court. Upon the case being called in the circuit court I as District Atty, moved to dismiss the appeal, because the appeal bond was informal, which motion was sustained by the court, and said appeal dismissed, the counsel for Mr Hartman, then took a bill

of exceptions to the Supreme court upon the ground that the circuit court refused to receive a new bond for Mr Hartman, which bond was tendered by him. The Supreme court affirmed the decision of the Circuit Court in dismissing the appeal and refusing to receive the new appeal bond. Mr Hartman had no counsel to represent him in the Justice Court.—I am satisfied that, if Mr Hartman, had had his case tried in the circuit court he would have been acquited—I as District Atty at the time think that it would be a hardship on Hartman to undergo the sentence of the Justice, and therefore respectfully, ask your excellency to remit the sentence of the Justice against Mr Hartman.

I have the honor to be
Respectfully your obt svt

Brookhaven Miss—
July 10th 1875—
Gv A K Davis
Dr Sir

Mr Frank Hartman some time since was convicted of selling spirituous liquors to a minor. He & his brother had at the time license to retail & the fact is as I am informed, that the liquor was not sold by Hartman but by a clerk in his establishment, without his knowledge or consent—He was not represented by counsel before the Justice of the Peace & took an appeal & by the neglect of the Justice the appeal bond was improperly prepared & hence the case was dismissed in the Circuit Court & H. was prevented from having it reviewed.—
A part of the sentence was imprisonment for ten days in jail—& it is this which he desires to have remitted—
I hope your Excelency
will find it consistent with your views of official duty to remit the imprison-ment.—
Very Truly Yrs
Frank Hartman

EXECUTIVE OFFICE,
STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.
Lincoln County.

From J. B. Deason et al.
